body: @badgh I'm not able to repro this on my Win10 machine.  I start powershell, then click 'x' to close and it exits immediately.  Does this repro with cmd on your machine?
May the cause due to third-party module?

Same Problem here after installing Windows 10 Anniversary Update, if I close powershell via exit command it quits instant. No third-party modules installed. Cmd does not have this problem, only powershell.

I agree with @mak42, the issue began after install of Windows 10 Anniversary Update, no third-party installed (it began exactly when I made clean install and further anniversary update of the system), cmd has no similar problem.

I tried to google this problem. In fact, the issue very much resembles https://github.com/lzybkr/PSReadLine/issues/17, and they suggest install ConsoleZ, I do not want install 3rd party consoles. Their issue was closed with the words 

> Closing - there is unlikely anything I can do about this. I guess you need to type exit if you want to exit faster.

which is today unacceptable, since as far as I understand PSReadline now is part of standard Powershell 5.0 and should work properly by default.
I also experience some weird artifacts if I use auto-complete tab. Apparently it disappears to fast to make a screenshot and if I record a video this artifacts aren't visible.
@badgh agree that this is unacceptable, we'll need to investigate
If we can support you in any way, please let us know.
Please make simple test: remove-module PSReadline and check whether the problem persists.
I did remove the PSReadline Folder in Program Files restarted Power Shell, apparently that didn't seem to help.
Let's check that the module isn't loaded. You can check loaded modules by means of `Get-Module` and unload the module by `Remove-Module PSReadline`.

lzybkr/PSReadline#17 was fixed a long time ago, so unless you're somehow using a really old version of PSReadline, I would assume something else is going on.

If you can repro in a debugger, maybe you can capture a stack trace for us - just break into the debugger before the process dies, hopefully we can get a useful stack from that.

Alternatively, maybe we can figure out what's going on with an ETW trace that you collect using [WPR](https://blogs.technet.microsoft.com/yongrhee/2015/08/04/windows-performance-recorder-wpr-exe-now-inbox-in-windows-10/) or [PerfView](https://github.com/Microsoft/perfview/releases).

@mak42 - if you are seeing artifacts during tab completion and can provide sufficient information to investigate or repro (e.g. capture a video), please open a new issue on [PSReadline](https://github.com/lzybkr/PSReadline/issues).

I have the same issue; Exit with typing an "exit" command quits immediately while exit with clicking on the "X" sign at top right of the Powershell window takes about 5 to 10 seconds, with a message saying (not responding) in the window banner; No suspicious event reported in the event logs. I have no idea where this comes from, but it did start (several months ago) after installing one of WIndows (insider?) updates.

Like @SteveL-MSFT - I can't reproduce this issue.  With three people reporting they can repro, hopefully someone can do some investigation to give us a clue what could be happening.

It would be helpful to know If you can repro with Win+R then `powershell -noprofile -command "sleep 300"`, then click on the X.  If that repros, I think we can eliminate the any modules (including PSReadline, which would not be loaded in this scenario) or something in your profile causing problems.

Just tried the command your proposed. Same behavior, using “x” the powershell windows takes 5 to 10 seconds to quit.

 

-Patrick

 

From: Jason Shirk [mailto:notifications@github.com] 
Sent: Wednesday, November 30, 2016 9:12 PM
To: PowerShell/PowerShell
Cc: Patrick-Gilles Maillot; Comment
Subject: Re: [PowerShell/PowerShell] Powershell hangs for a while on close (when X button pressed) (#2804)

 

Like @SteveL-MSFT <https://github.com/SteveL-MSFT>  - I can't reproduce this issue. With three people reporting they can repro, hopefully someone can do some investigation to give us a clue what could be happening.

It would be helpful to know If you can repro with Win+R then powershell -noprofile -command "sleep 300", then click on the X. If that repros, I think we can eliminate the any modules (including PSReadline, which would not be loaded in this scenario) or something in your profile causing problems.

—

I confirm this does not happen using a cmd window.

-Patrick

All work good on Windows 10 5.1.14971.1000 

```powershell
$PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      5.1.14971.1000
PSEdition                      Desktop
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
BuildVersion                   10.0.14971.1000
CLRVersion                     4.0.30319.42000
WSManStackVersion              3.0
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
```

```powershell
PS C:\Program Files\PowerShell\6.0.0.13> $PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
WSManStackVersion              3.0
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
GitCommitId                    v6.0.0-alpha.13
PSEdition                      Core
PSVersion                      6.0.0-alpha
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
CLRVersion
BuildVersion                   3.0.0.0

```
Is there a way to totally reinstall powershell with all modules (clean and then install this new version 5.1.14971.1000)?
May be install new Windows 10 Preview build.

I totally reinstalled Windows again, now it's ok for me. But I suppose the problem is maybe due to some Antivirus activity burden. For example, I installed and uninstalled AVG Free Antivirus, and noted that it causes some delay to Powershell closing (although not as bad as it was initially when I asked the question).
@badgh good to hear, I'll resolve this as external for now unless we have something we can investigate.  thanks.

Nice catch!

 

Reading your post and not changing anything to my PC configuration, 

I disabled AVG:

Exit from powershell (using the x button) is instantaneous.

Re-enabling all but the “Computer Protection” (the leftmost option of AVG GUI window)

Exit from powershell (using the x button) is instantaneous.

Re-enabling the “Computer Protection” (the leftmost option of AVG GUI window)

Exit from powershell (using the x button) hangs again for 5 to 10 seconds before being effective.

 

So it looks more like an AVG issue than a Windows powershell problem.

 

Thanks for pointing to this.

 

-Patrick

Issue reported onto the AVG support forum.

 

-Patrick

I disabled AVG:

Exit from powershell (using the x button) is instantaneous.

Re-enabling the “Computer Protection” (the leftmost option of AVG GUI window)

Exit from powershell (using the x button) hangs again for 5 to 10 seconds before being effective.

 

So it looks more like an AVG issue than a Windows powershell problem.

 

Thanks for pointing to this.

 

-Patrick
